Award.AwardTitle: Academic Excellence Through Research and Mentoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Shaw University's HBCU-UP project, Academic Excellence through Research and Mentoring, is aimed at enhancing the quality of STEM majors for admission to graduate schools, increase the flow of minority students from high schools and community colleges into STEM programs at Shaw University, build technology infrastructure including a testing/tutorial center and provide faculty development activities to increase grant capability and undergraduate research involvement.

Shaw University has outlined an aggressive recruitment plan which includes family support activities, mentoring, tracking, and providing enrichment to the academic program such as internships, field trips, and conference attendance.

The academic component of the project will focus on strengthening the technology infrastructure and the traditional gatekeeper courses in mathematics and physics. Funds will be used to equip a testing and tutorial center, as well as classrooms, and enhancing the living environment to support STEM student living-learning communities. The technology enhancement will be closely linked to the curriculum initiatives.

The classroom instruction will be enhanced with the use of the computerized learning system developed at Clark Atlanta University. This delivery system includes multimedia lecture notes, and online testing and management. Other curriculum enhancements will include discovery approach for general chemistry courses, as well as innovative physics experiments.

Faculty development activities in this implementation project will focus on strengthening faculty ability to obtain and manage grant funds, as well as increase faculty involvement in undergraduate research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall purpose of the NSF funded Academic Excelence Project was in direct response to the academic and social needs of Shaw’s African American males and females who continue to be disproportionately underrepresented in the workforce and to fill the gap of minority representation in basic and applied research in the scientific community. It served as a launching pad for the establishment of collaborations and lasting partnerships with scientists at Research I institutions in a manner that will help to increase the number of Minority students who pursue research careers in fields where the number of African Americans is very low.

During the previous four years of the NSF funded Academic Excelence Project, we offered the Science Outreach Summer Academy (SOSA) which focused on recruitment, retention and counseling of minority students through an intensive six-week summer program in mathematics, physical science, and English. However, the final summer we provided summer research assistantships that engaged our rising sophomore, junior, and senior students in the research process. These assistantships were a progression of the SOSA program where the emphasis was to build their research skills by engaging underrepresented minority female and male students in research. This program was employed to increase minority participation in the science and mathematics fields and enhance problem solving and critical thinking skills.  

The project did shed light on a retention issue occurring with biology majors. Natural Sciences faculty noted the impact the scholarships had on majors who were trying to balance work and school demands. Scholarships and stipends eased the need to seek outside employment and redirect focus on classroom attendance and grades. Students were more available to participate as research mentees, which afforded them the benefit of engaging in research projects and poster presentations.
